__notes.field_Front: Direct use of __import__() is discouraged in favor of {{c1::importlib.import_module()}}
{{c1::ascii()}} generates a string similar to that returned by repr() in Python 2
the {{c1::ascii()}} built-in function escapes non-ASCII characters using the backslash x, u, and U escapes
when you replace non-ASCII chars with backslash x, y and U, these are called {{c1::escapes}}
the bin() built-in function converts an integer number to a {{c1::binary string}} prefixed with {{c1::'0b'}}
bin(3) outputs {{c1::'0b11'}}
in bin(x) if x is not an int object, it must {{c1::define an __index__() method}} that {{c1::results in an integer}}
in format(14, x) what does x have to be for the result to be '0b1110'? {{c1::'#b'}}
in format(14, x) what does x have to be for the result to be '1110'? {{c1::'b'}}
within a formatted string, what does the formatted field look like to turn 13 into binary with no binary prefix {{c1:: {13:b} }}
the bool class is a subclass of {{c1::int}}
breakpoint() was introduced in {{c1::3.7}}
breakpoint() drops you in the debugger at the {{c1::call site}}
The {{c1::bytearray}} class is a mutable sequence of integers in the range 0 <= x < 256
The bytearray class is a mutable sequence of integers in the range  {{c1::0 <= x < 256}}
bytearray built-in: if 'source' in function call is an object conforming to the buffer interface, a {{c1::read-only buffer of the object}} will be used to initialize the bytes array.
{{c1::bytes}} is an immutable version of bytearray
bytes is an immutable version of {{c1::bytearray}}
bytearray vs. bytes: which one can also be created with literals? {{c1::bytes}}
what this outputs and why: list(b'A') {{c1::[65] because b'A' is byte literal syntax, and list() translates bytes arrays into integers}}
b'A' is {{c1::byte literal}} syntax
bytes and bytearray are binary {{c1::sequence}} types
classes are callable.  doing so {{c1::returns a new instance}}
instances are callable if {{c1::their class has a __call__() method}}
built-in function that returns the string representing a character whose Unicode code point is the integer i: {{c1::chr(i)}}
chr() is the inverse of {{c1::ord()}}
chr(): {{c1::ValueError}} will be raised if i is outside the range of 0 through 1,114,111
A class method receives the {{c1::class}} as {{c1::implicit}} first argument
transform a method into a class method with the built-in {{c1::classmethod}}
compile: Compile the source into a {{c1::code}} or {{c1::AST}} object
compile: Code objects can be executed by {{c1::exec()}} or {{c1::eval()}}
compile: The {{c1::filename}} argument should give the file from which the code was read
compile: The {{c1::filename}} argument should give the file from which the code was read
compile built-in: if the source wasn’t read from a file {{c1::'<string>'}} is commonly used for the filename argument
compile built-in: {{c1::mode}} argument specifies what kind of code must be compiled
compile built-in, 'mode': {{c1::'exec'}} if source consists of a sequence of statements
compile built-in, 'mode': {{c1::'eval'}} if it consists of a single expression
compile built-in, 'mode': {{c1::'single'}} if it consists of a single interactive statement
compile built-in: when mode argument is 'single' {{c1::expression statements}} that evaluate to something other than None will be printed
compile built-in: The optional arguments 'flags' and 'dont_inherit' control which {{c1::future statements}} affect the compilation of source
compile built-in: The argument {{c1::optimize}} specifies the optimization level of the compiler
compile built-in: The argument 'optimize' defaults to -1, which selects the optimization level of the interpreter as given by {{c1::-O}} options
If you want to parse Python code into its AST representation, see {{c1::ast.parse()}}
In your documentation you can skip running doctest on prompt commands with {{c1::# doctest: +SKIP}}
The built-in function {{c1::delattr(x, 'foobar')}} is equivalent to del x.foobar
dir(object): the object has a method named {{c1::__dir__()}}, this method will be called and must return the list of attributes.
dir(object): If the object does not provide {{c1::__dir__()}}, the function tries its best to gather information from the object's __dict__ attribute, if defined, and from its type object.
dir(object): If the object does not provide __dir__(), the function tries its best to gather information from the object's {{c1::__dict__}} attribute, if defined, and from its type object.
dir(object): The resulting list is not necessarily complete, and may be inaccurate when the object has a custom {{c1::__getattr__()}}
dir() built-in function: {{c1::metaclass attributes}} are not in the result list when the argument is a class.
The built-in function {{c1::divmod}} takes two (non complex) numbers as arguments and return a pair of numbers consisting of their quotient and remainder when using integer division.
The eval optional keyword parameters are {{c1::globals}} and {{c1::locals}}
See {{c1::ast.literal_eval()}} for a function that can safely evaluate strings with expressions containing only literals.
the module that provides direct access to all ‘built-in’ identifiers of Python is {{c1::builtins}}
exec(): you can control what builtins are available to the executed code by inserting your own {{c1::__builtins__}} dictionary into globals before passing it to exec()
filter(): See {{c1::itertools.filterfalse()}} for the complementary function that returns elements of iterable for which function returns false.
float(): you can make infinity by doing: {{c1::float('Infinity')}} (long style) or {{c1::float('inf')}} (short style)
int, float, complex are {{c1::numeric types}}
the name of the second parameter: format(value[, {{c1::format_spec}} ])
format(): The default format_spec is an empty string which usually gives the same effect as calling {{c1::str(value)}}
A call to format(value, format_spec) is translated to type(value).__format__(value, format_spec) which bypasses the {{c1::instance dictionary}} when searching for the value’s __format__() method
A call to format(value, format_spec) is translated to {{c1::type(value).__format__(value, format_spec)}} which bypasses the instance dictionary when searching for the value’s __format__() method
Hash values are {{c1::integers}}
hash() values are used to quickly compare {{c1::dictionary keys}} during a dictionary lookup
For objects with custom __hash__() methods, note that hash() {{c1::truncates}} the return value based on the {{c1::bit width}} of the host machine
The help function is added to the built-in namespace by the {{c1::site}} module
hex(): the hexadecimal string returned is prefixed with {{c1::'0x'}}
the shorthand formatted string literal syntax for showing the hex representation of 255 (with the '0x' prefix) is {{c1::'%#x' % 255}}
hex: formatted string literal that returns '0xff' {{c1::f'{255:#x}'}}
hex: formatted string literal that returns 'ff' {{c1::f'{255:x}'}}
hex: formatted string literal that returns 'FF' (uppercase) {{c1::f'{255:X}'}}
To obtain a hexadecimal string representation for a float, use the {{c1::float.hex()}} method
In CPython the id of an object is {{c1::the address of the object in memory}}
If the {{c1::readline}} module was loaded, then input() will use it to provide elaborate line editing and history features
input() built-in: When EOF is read, {{c1::EOFError}} is raised
int builtin: For floating point numbers, the {{c1::__trunc__}} method on the object is used
int builtin: For floating point numbers, int {{c1::truncates towards zero}}
int builtin: another way of saying base 10 is {{c1::radix 10}}
int builtin: if the x in int(x) is not a number, then it must be one of these three types: {{c1::string, bytes, bytearray}}
int builtin: the value for 'a' in a string in x in int(x) is {{c1::10}}
int builtin: the value for 'z' in a string in x in int(x) is {{c1::35}}
int builtin: A base-n literal consists of the digits 0 to {{c1::n-1}}
int builtin: if you do int('z', WHAT_BASE), (where 'z' is equal to 35) then what base must you use and why? {{c1::36 because allowed digits are 0 through the base-1}}
int builtin: Base-2, -8, and -16 literals have the prefixes {{c1::0b}} , {{c1::0o}} , and {{c1::0x}}
int builtin: interpret x string as whatever prefix it supplies (like '0b' or '0x') in int(x, WHAT_BASE).  What is WHAT_BASE? {{c1::0}}
int builtin: the int function signature is {{c1::int(x, base=10)}}
isinstance builtin: classinfo argument can be a {{c1::type}} or a {{c1::tuple of types (and can be a recursive set of tuples)}}
issubclass builtin: in issubclass(class, classinfo) there are three types of subclass of classinfo that the class can be: {{c1::(direct, indirect or virtual)}}
iter builtin: an object can support the iteration protocol by supplying the {{c1::__iter__()}} method
iter builtin: an object can support the sequence protocol by supplying the {{c1::__getitem__()}} method
iter builtin: in iter(object) the object must support one of two protocols: the {{c1::iteration}} protocol or the {{c1::sequence}} protocol
iter builtin: if the second argument, {{c1::sentinel}} is given, then object must be {{c1::a callable object}}
iter builtin: if the optional sentinel argument is passed, the iterator created will call the object with {{c1::no arguments}} for each call to its __next__() method
iter builtin: if the optional sentinel argument is passed, if the value returned by __next__() is equal to sentinel, {{c1::StopIteration}} will be raised
iter builtin: a function that reads fixed-width blocks from a binary database file until the end of file is reached is called a {{c1::block-reader}}
len builtin: Return the length (the number of {{c1::items}}) of an object.
len builtin: The argument may be a {{c1::sequence}} (such as a string, bytes, tuple, list, or range) or a {{c1::collection}} (such as a dictionary, set, or frozen set).
locals builtin: Update and return a dictionary representing the current local {{c1::symbol table}}.
{{c1::Free variables}} are returned by locals() when it is called in function blocks, but not in class blocks.
Free variables are returned by locals() when it is called in {{c1::function}} blocks, but not in {{c1::class}} blocks.
map builtin: For cases where the function inputs are already arranged into {{c1::argument tuples}}, see itertools.starmap().
map builtin: the function signature is: {{c1::map(function, iterable, ...)}}
map builtin: if multiple iterables are provided, the mapping stops when {{c1::the shortest iterable is exhausted}}
max builtin: returns the {{c1::largest item in an iterable xx or xx the largest argument if multiple arguments are supplied}}
max builtin: The {{c1::default}} argument specifies an object to return if the provided iterable is empty.
max builtin: a ValueError is raised if {{c1::the iterable is empty}} and {{c1::default}} is not provided
{{c1::memoryview}} objects allow Python code to access the internal data of an object that supports the buffer protocol without copying
memoryview objects allow Python code to access the internal data of an object that supports the {{c1::buffer protocol}} without copying
min(): if multiple items are minimal, the function returns the first one encountered. This is consistent with other {{c1::sort-stability}} preserving tools
next(): If the second, optional argument {{c1::default}} is given, it is returned if the iterator is exhausted, otherwise {{c1:: StopIteration}} is raised
{{c1::object}} is a base for all classes
{{c1::object}} has the methods that are common to all instances of Python classes
object does not {{c1::have a __dict__}}, so you can’t assign arbitrary attributes to an instance of the object class
{{c1::oct()}} converts an integer number to an {{c1::octal string}} prefixed with '0o'
ord: Given a string representing one {{c1::Unicode character}}, return an {{c1::integer}} representing the {{c1::Unicode code point}} of it
ord: is the inverse of {{c1::chr()}}
pow: the third argument, z, is used to take the {{c1::modulo}} of x to the power of y, and is there because it is more performant
pow: The two-argument form pow(x, y) is equivalent to using the power operator: {{c1::x**y}}
pow: with {{c1::mixed}} operand types, the coercion rules for {{c1::binary arithmetic operators}} apply
the print function prints objects to the {{c1::text stream}} given as the file argument
print: output is followed by whatever is specified in the {{c1::end}} argument (newline is the default)
print: if you do not specify the {{c1::file}} argument, sys.stdout will be used
print: if you do not want to buffer output, you can pass the {{c1::flush=True}} argument
property: you can make a method that deletes an instance attribute __x by using this decorator: {{c1::@x.deleter}}
range is actually an {{c1::immutable sequence}} type
An object can support the sequence protocol by providing the {{c1::__len__()}} method and the {{c1::__getitem__()}} method
The second, optional argument to the round function is {{c1::ndigits}}.
round(0.5) rounds to {{c1::0}}, and round(1.5) rounds to {{c1::2}}
one way you can create a set is by passing the set function an {{c1::iterator}}
An alternative way of doing x.foobar = 123 using a built-in function is {{c1::setattr(x, 'foobar', 123)}}
{{c1::itertools.islice()}} is an alternate version of the slice function, where it returns an iterator
The built-in sorted() function is guaranteed to be {{c1::stable}}
A static method does not receive an {{c1::implicit first argument}}
You can use the {{c1::staticmethod}} function when you need a reference to a function from a class body and you want to avoid the automatic transformation to instance method
if you want to make sure that a function in a class is not passed an implicit first argument you can {{c1::use the @staticmethod function decorator}}
To add floating point values with extended precision, use {{c1::math.fsum()}}
To concatenate a series of iterables, consider using {{c1::itertools.chain()}}
super built-in: returns a {{c1::proxy}} object
super built-in: the super proxy object delegates method calls to {{c1::a parent or sibling class}} of type.
super built-in: the search order is same as that used by {{c1::getattr()}} except {{c1::that the type itself is skipped}}
super built-in: the {{c1::__mro__}} attribute of the type (first argument) lists the method resolution search order used by both getattr() and super().
super built-in: the __mro__ attribute of the type (first argument) lists the {{c1::method resolution search order}} used by both getattr() and super().
super built-in: The {{c1::__mro__}} attribute is dynamic and can change whenever the inheritance hierarchy is updated.
super built-in: If the second argument is omitted, the super object returned is {{c1::unbound}}.
super built-in: If the second argument is an object, {{c1::isinstance(obj, type)}} must be true.
super built-in: If the second argument is a type, {{c1::issubclass(type2, type)}} must be true
super built-in: The second, python-specific use case is to support {{c1::cooperative multiple inheritance}} in a dynamic execution environment.
super built-in: cooperative multiple inheritance in a dynamic execution environment makes it possible to implement {{c1::'diamond diagrams'}}
super built-in: if your method definition looks like this, def method(self, arg): , you would use super like this: {{c1::super().method(arg)}}
super built-in: super() is implemented as part of the {{c1::binding process}} for explicit dotted attribute lookups such as super().__getitem__(name).
super built-in: super() is implemented as part of the binding process for {{c1::explicit dotted attribute lookups}} such as super().__getitem__(name).

super built-in: super() is implemented as part of the binding process for explicit dotted attribute lookups such as super().__getitem__(name) by implementing ist own {{c1::__getattribute__() method}} for searching classes

super built-in: super() is implemented as part of the binding process for explicit dotted attribute lookups such as super().__getitem__(name) by implementing ist own {{c1::__getattribute__() method}} for searching classes
super built-in: implements its own __getattribute__() method for searching classes in a predictable order that supports {{c1::cooperative multiple inheritance}}.
super built-in: the zero argument form only works inside {{c1::a class definition}}
tuple built-in: rather than being a function, tuple is actually an {{c1::immutable sequence type}}
type built-in: the return value is a {{c1::type object}}
type built-in: the return value is generally the same object as returned by {{c1::object.__class__}}
{{c1::isinstance()}} built-in function is recommended for testing the type of an object, because it takes {{c1::subclasses}} into account
type built-in: With three arguments, return {{c1::a new type object}}
type built-in: returning a new type object is essentially a dynamic form of {{c1::the class statement}}
type built-in: using the type function, you can make the equivalent to class X: a = 1 by doing: {{c1::X = type('X', (object,), dict(a=1))}}
{{c1::vars}} returns the __dict__ attribute for a module, class, instance, or any other object with a __dict__ attribute
objects such as {{c1::modules}} and {{c1::instances}} have an updateable __dict__ attribute
classes use a {{c1::types.MappingProxyType}} to prevent direct dictionary updates
related to the vars builtin: classes use a types.MappingProxyType to {{c1::prevent direct dictionary updates}}
without an argument, vars() acts like {{c1::locals()}}
without an argument, {{c1::vars()}} acts like locals()
zip builtin: returns {{c1::an iterator of tuples}}
zip builtin: with a single iterable argument, it returns {{c1::an iterator of 1-tuples}}
zip builtin: if you care about the trailing values in longer iterables, use {{c1::itertools.zip_longest()}} instead
